title: The Best Ways to Clean Your UGG Slippers at Home

steps.title: Brush your slippers to remove dirt and dust.
steps.content: Brush your slippers to remove dirt and dust. Use a soft-bristled suede brush for the best results, but a soft nylon brush or toothbrush can work in a pinch. Start at the top of your slippers and gently brush down toward the soles. Follow the direction of the nap to help fluff it back up and remove dirty surface stains. [1] X Research source Be sure to check the soles of your shoes as well. Brush out any dirt or debris that’s caught in them.

steps.title: Treat dry stains with a suede eraser.
steps.content: Treat dry stains with a suede eraser . Rub the stain gently using a circular motion. The eraser can help break apart stubborn surface stains and help refresh the nap. [2] X Research source A standard pencil eraser works well if you don’t have a suede eraser on hand. Be gentle when you use a suede eraser because pressing too hard can flatten or damage the nap. If you have grease or oil stains on your slippers, shoe care specialist Marc Sigal recommends “adding some sort of like chalk or talcum powder directly to the affected area itself and then just letting it sit overnight.” He adds that the powder can help soak up the stain and then you can just brush it off with a soft-bristled brush.

steps.title: Dampen the slippers with cold water.
steps.content: Dampen the slippers with cold water. Wet a soft cloth with clean, cold water and wring it out. Wipe the outer material on your UGG slippers so they’re damp. [3] X Research source It’s normal for your slippers to look darker in color when they’re wet. Once they dry, they’ll have their original color.

steps.title: Wash your UGG slippers with suede cleaner.
steps.content: Wash your UGG slippers with suede cleaner. Either use suede shampoo or make your own with equal parts cold water and distilled white vinegar. Dip a clean cloth in your cleaner and gently work it into the material at the top of your slippers. Use small circular motions to scrub your slippers, and work toward the bottom. [4] X Research source Steer clear of using dish soap to clean your UGGs because it could cause discoloration or damage.

steps.title: Rinse your slippers with a damp cloth.
steps.content: Rinse your slippers with a damp cloth. Wet a new cloth with cold water and wring it out. Wipe the entire outsides of your slippers with the cloth to lift up any residual cleaner. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Stuff your slippers with paper towels and leave them to air-dry.
steps.content: Stuff your slippers with paper towels and leave them to air-dry. Crumple up newspapers and push them into the toe of your slippers so they retain their shape as they dry. Leave your slippers in a cool, dry place for about a day so they can dry completely. [6] X Research source Avoid putting your shoes in direct sunlight or near heat sources because it could damage the material.

steps.title: Brush your slippers with a suede brush to restore the material.
steps.content: Brush your slippers with a suede brush to restore the material. Once your UGGs are dry, take your soft suede brush and fluff the nap on your slippers. Work from the top of the slippers toward the soles in small, gentle strokes. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the lining with soapy water.
steps.content: Scrub the lining with soapy water. Add a small squirt of dish soap to a bowl of cold water, and mix it together. Wet a soft clean cloth in the water, wring it out, and gently rub the insides of your slippers. Gently work the suds into the material to help clean up any dirt or debris that’s caught inside. [8] X Research source Always wring out your cleaning cloth so it isn’t soaking wet while you’re cleaning. Use a soft-bristled toothbrush to clean hard-to-reach areas, like the toes of your slippers.

steps.title: Wipe the soap out with a clean, damp cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the soap out with a clean, damp cloth. Use a fresh cloth and wet it under cold water. Wring out the cloth so it’s not soaking wet, and start wiping up the leftover suds. Rinse as much of the soapy water as you can. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Let your slippers air-dry overnight before wearing them.
steps.content: Let your slippers air-dry overnight before wearing them. Keep your slippers in a cool dry spot and out of direct sunlight. Leave the slippers out until they’re completely dry on the inside.

steps.title: Leave baking soda in your slippers overnight to remove odors.
steps.content: Leave baking soda in your slippers overnight to remove odors. Sigal recommends to “just put in some baking soda or cornstarch inside the shoes, and leave them for a few hours overnight” so it absorbs the odors. In the morning, he says to “vacuum [the baking soda] out using a small vacuum.”

steps.title: UGG Cleaner and Conditioner
steps.content: UGG Cleaner and Conditioner UGG makes their own Cleaner and Conditioner solution that’s specifically made for their slippers and boots. They also offer complete cleaning kits containing the cleaner and brushes. Pros: Made specifically for cleaning UGGs, simple to use, and won’t damage the material Cons: May be more expensive than other similar cleaners Customer Ratings: 4.3 star average on Amazon

steps.title: Suede shampoo
steps.content: Suede shampoo Suede shampoo works well for the sheepskin material on UGGs because it helps restore the nap without leaving behind any stains or damage. One of the most popular suede shampoos is Pink Miracle Shoe Cleaner . Pros: Works on all materials, non-toxic solution, and only takes a few drops for an effective clean Cons: Small bottle will run out faster Customer Ratings: 4.3 star average on Amazon

steps.title: Suede eraser
steps.content: Suede eraser Suede erasers break apart stains and residue caught in the slipper material, and they work similar to pencil erasers. Just rub the mark with the eraser, and it will lighten up or disappear. A favorite choice for users is the Kiwi Suede and Nubuck Stain Eraser . Pros: Easy to use, removes scuffs and scratches easily, and small enough to bring with you when you’re on the go Cons: Won’t always work on larger, deep-set stains, Customer Ratings: 4.3 star average on Amazon

steps.title: No, keep UGG slippers out of your washing machine.
steps.content: No, keep UGG slippers out of your washing machine. Because UGGs are made from delicate sheepskin and leather, a washing machine may damage your slippers. Stick to washing UGG slippers by hand so they continue to look great. While some people have successfully cleaned their UGGs using a delicate cycle with cold water, try it at your own risk.

steps.title: Brush your slippers after each wear.
steps.content: Brush your slippers after each wear. Any time you wear your slippers out or around your home for a long time, use your suede brush to clean off any dirt. Always start from the top and work your way down to the soles so you don’t spread debris onto areas you’ve already cleaned. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Apply stain and water repellent to your UGGs.
steps.content: Apply stain and water repellent to your UGGs. Stain and water repellent adds a coating to your slippers that repels moisture so they’re less likely to stain. While the instructions vary on which repellent you use, they are generally applied pretty similar. [11] X Research source Work outside or in a well-ventilated area. Hold the spray about 6 in (15 cm) from your slippers. Spray your slippers with an even coat of spray. Let your slippers dry for 24 hours before wearing them. Brush your slippers with a suede brush to restore the nap.

steps.title: Treat stains as soon as you notice them.
steps.content: Treat stains as soon as you notice them. Stains are easier to remove when they’re fresh and still wet. Try to blot up as much of the stain as you can with a paper towel or a soft cleaning cloth. Clean your UGG slippers right away to keep the mark from setting in. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Wear your slippers inside only.
steps.content: Wear your slippers inside only. Rather than wearing your UGGs slippers outside where they could get dirty or wet, keep them indoors so they’re less likely to get exposed to messes. [13] X Research source When you’re not wearing your slippers, keep them in a closet to keep them safe and clean.
